page.title: 01An inn at Greve de Lecq
page.content: Le Moulin de Lecq Inn was a 600 year old flour mill until 1929. Soon the Germans came and turned it into a large generator for the searchlights they used. It became a public inn in 1955. The wheel at le Moulin de Lecq Inn weighs at least 18 tons and has a 21 foot diameter. The wheel is made of wood. A stream flows from the woods underneath the wheel out into Greve de Lecq beach. The girls at Le Moulin de Lecq wear Breton costumes. Some things like paraffin lamps are still used at the Inn. The old stable bar looks nice and peaceful on the outside but inside it's like any other pub. This bar sells fresh crab sandwiches. They cost 75p each. They sell assorted rolls and sandwiches. Every Monday there's Simon Curzon singing country and western songs.
